senses.sense: a belief or idea that influences the way you think or behave
senses.dict_examp: Our school promotes an ethic of service to the community.
senses.lear_examp: Though I am no longer a believer, I agree with the whole religious ethic, and I shall transmit it to my children.

senses.sense: the act of considering something carefully and deciding how good or bad it is
senses.dict_examp: There was no evaluation of the risks involved.
senses.lear_examp: And that is what counts in the evaluation of job candidates.

senses.sense: used to emphasize something that is surprising
senses.dict_examp: Everyone danced - even Mick.
senses.lear_examp: You were the only one who wasn't there, even Marcelo was there!

senses.sense: used to emphasize a comparison
senses.dict_examp: Her last film was even better.
senses.lear_examp: When I saw her getting off the train I really was close to breaking down because she looked even more beautiful.

senses.sense: used to emphasize the fact that something does not happen or is not true
senses.dict_examp: "I never cry." "Not even when you hurt yourself really badly?"
senses.lear_examp: We tried to fish, but didn't catch a thing, not even a shoe!

senses.sense: whether or not
senses.dict_examp: Even if you take a taxi, you'll still miss your train.
senses.lear_examp: I often go to parks, with or without the children, even if the weather is not good.

senses.sense: although
senses.dict_examp: Even though he left school at 16, he still managed to become a millionaire.
senses.lear_examp: They didn't give up hope even though they were tired and wet to the bone.

senses.sense: used to emphasize that something surprising is true despite what you have just said
senses.dict_examp: Car prices have gone down a lot, but even so, we couldn't afford to buy one.
senses.lear_examp: I'm sure many of these things happened due to bad luck, but even so, there are some arrangements that, I believe, can easily be improved.

senses.sense: to make as much money as you spent, but no more
senses.dict_examp: The company only managed to break even this year.
senses.lear_examp: Company C does not seem to be doing well. In the year 2000, it just seems to be breaking even.

senses.sense: a period of time in history that is special for a particular reason
senses.dict_examp: the Clinton era
senses.lear_examp: The world is paddling through the era of technology.

senses.sense: moving stairs that take people from one level of a building to another
senses.dict_examp: I'll meet you by the up/down escalator on the second floor.
senses.lear_examp: The newly decorated section is fairly modern in style with escalators and touch-screen ticket machines.

senses.sense: If soil, stone, etc., erodes or is eroded, it is gradually damaged by water or wind.
senses.dict_examp: The coastline is slowly being eroded.
senses.lear_examp: The areas of Sayago - in the Spanish province of Zamora - and Tras-os-Montes, in Portugal, are joined by a natural border: the river Duero and the rocky canyon that has been eroded for millions of years by the action of the water.

senses.sense: to gradually destroy something such as a quality or situation or to make it weaker
senses.dict_examp: Budget cuts could further erode the benefit package provided for by the contract.
senses.lear_examp: Competition can erode a child's confidence.

senses.sense: the unit of money used in most European Union countries; €
senses.dict_examp: Most hotels are priced between a hundred and two hundred euros a night.
senses.lear_examp: The price is 50 euro.

senses.sense: a short piece of writing about a particular subject, especially one done by students
senses.dict_examp: For homework I want you to write an essay on endangered species.
senses.lear_examp: I could write an extra essay.

senses.sense: equal in amount, value, importance, or meaning
senses.dict_examp: The UK's Brit Awards are roughly equivalent to the Oscars.
senses.lear_examp: The 35-49 year old group started in 1990 with an attendance figure of 60 percent, almost equivalent to the age group of the 25-34 year olds.

senses.sense: something that has the same value, importance, size, or meaning as something else
senses.dict_examp: She won the equivalent of $5 million.
senses.lear_examp: Most technical terms have Latin roots and are very similar to their German equivalent.

senses.sense: relating to a large group of people who have the same national, racial, or cultural origins
senses.dict_examp: an ethnic neighborhood
senses.lear_examp: Over 98% of the population are ethnic Chinese.

senses.sense: a small piece of rubber that is used to remove pencil marks from paper
senses.dict_examp: I usually have pencils and an eraser in my backpack.
senses.lear_examp: You will have to bring a pencil, an eraser and a notebook.

senses.sense: very much or particularly
senses.dict_examp: She's not especially interested in sports.
senses.lear_examp: I like sports, especially playing basketball.

senses.sense: to remove writing or other marks from something by rubbing it with a piece of rubber or with a cloth
senses.dict_examp: I kept changing my mind and erasing my answers on the test.
senses.lear_examp: The dozen notebooks she had written, erased, tore apart and thrown in the trash can didn't bother her now.

senses.sense: guessed
senses.dict_examp: an estimated cost/value
senses.lear_examp: My estimated time of arrival at Heathrow airport is nine o'clock in the morning and my flight number is OK 1312.

senses.sense: a large area of land in the country which is owned by a family or an organization and is often used for growing crops or raising animals
senses.dict_examp: a country estate
senses.lear_examp: There is a special law in Sweden which allows everyone to wander through any private estate unless one causes harm.

senses.sense: a group of houses or factories built in a planned way
senses.dict_examp: a housing estate
senses.lear_examp: I live on a big housing estate.

senses.sense: every person
senses.dict_examp: Everyone agreed with me.
senses.lear_examp: Almost everyone went to the party.

senses.sense: at any time
senses.dict_examp: Have you ever been to London?
senses.lear_examp: It is the most beautiful place I've ever seen.

senses.sense: almost never
senses.dict_examp: We hardly ever go out these days.
senses.lear_examp: Well, nowadays I hardly ever watch television, as time is something that I really don't have enough to spend.

senses.sense: continuously since that time

senses.lear_examp: The pen was given to me by my father on my birthday and I have treasured it ever since.

senses.sense: always in the future
senses.dict_examp: I'm not going to live here for ever.
senses.lear_examp: My friend  was leaving the city for ever and going to a city in another country.

senses.sense: better/faster/happier, etc. than at any time before
senses.dict_examp: She is running faster than ever.
senses.lear_examp: As for the students' exam results, they are better than ever.

senses.sense: always changing/growing/increasing, etc.
senses.dict_examp: We live in an ever-changing world.
senses.lear_examp: In our ever-changing society, in the affluent cities of the Western world, life moves at such a fast pace that parents are the reflection and the result of our times, the cogs of a large, rather uncontrollable wheel.

senses.sense: all things
senses.dict_examp: The thieves took everything.
senses.lear_examp: We have to bring a pencil, they'll give us everything else we need.

senses.sense: to be the most important part of someone's life
senses.dict_examp: His children mean everything to him.
senses.lear_examp: I think that every person has a different opinion, but for me, money and fame isn't everything in life.

senses.sense: to do everything that you are able and allowed to do
senses.dict_examp: I've done everything in my power to help him.
senses.lear_examp: She will not allow the new Mrs. de Winter to become the lady of Manderly and will do everything in her power to stop her.

senses.sense: something that happens, especially something important or unusual
senses.dict_examp: Local people have been shocked by recent events in town.
senses.lear_examp: I like this book because I like the description of historical events.

senses.sense: a race, party, competition, etc. that has been organized for a particular time
senses.dict_examp: Over two thousand people took part in the event.
senses.lear_examp: When there are parties or important social events, I usually choose a dress to wear.

senses.sense: if something happens

senses.lear_examp: In the event of bad weather, it would be wise to plan an alternative to the boat trip, for example a visit of Buckingham Palace or the Houses of Parliament.

senses.sense: whatever happens
senses.dict_examp: I'm not sure if I'm coming on Friday, but in any event, I'll see you next week.
senses.lear_examp: In any event, it is incumbent upon all of us to carefully plan our travel matters, so as to take advantage of their several benefits.

senses.sense: the way in which a situation develops, especially a sudden or unexpected change
senses.dict_examp: We were all shocked by this tragic turn of events.
senses.lear_examp: She was not prepared for such an unexpected turn of events!

senses.sense: each one of a group of people or things
senses.dict_examp: Every time I go to New Jersey I get caught in a traffic jam.
senses.lear_examp: I like every country or place, where the weather is hot.

senses.sense: used to show that something is repeated regularly
senses.dict_examp: He goes to Ireland every summer.
senses.lear_examp: She cooks every afternoon.

senses.sense: as much as is possible

senses.lear_examp: The man realized that people should take every opportunity that life offers them, because all we are is dust in the wind.

senses.sense: sometimes, but not often

senses.lear_examp: Each day choose 10 new words and learn them by heart. In a week you will have learned 70 new words, and in a year 3640, a lot of words. Please, do not forget to repeat them every now and then.

senses.sense: sometimes, but not often
senses.dict_examp: He went into town every so often to buy supplies.
senses.lear_examp: And likewise, common sense tells us it doesn't matter that oranges from Spain contain 0.01% more vitamin C than those from Florida, as long as we eat them every once in a while.

senses.sense: happening every two days/weeks, etc., not each day/week, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Alice goes to the gym every other day.
senses.lear_examp: First, I would run 2 miles every other day, but soon it became a need to do it on a daily basis.

senses.sense: every person
senses.dict_examp: Everybody thought it was a good idea.
senses.lear_examp: I was so happy, because everybody had a good time.

senses.sense: something that makes you believe that something is true or exists
senses.dict_examp: evidence of global warming
senses.lear_examp: David started looking for evidence, but he found nothing.

senses.sense: information that is given or objects that are shown in a court of law to help to prove if someone has committed a crime
senses.dict_examp: He was arrested despite the lack of evidence against him.
senses.lear_examp: My new neighbour murdered his wife and although the circumstantial evidence against him was enormous, the case was dismissed because of the lack of some clinching piece of evidence.

senses.sense: obvious to everyone and easy to see or understand

senses.sense: used when you are giving or asking for information that is completely correct

senses.lear_examp: I don't know exactly what time I'll arrive.

senses.sense: used to emphasize what you are saying

senses.lear_examp: That is exactly one of the reasons why I decided to join a new English class.

senses.sense: something you say when you agree completely with someone

senses.sense: used to say that something is not completely true
senses.dict_examp: "So you gave her your book?" "Not exactly, I lent it to her."

senses.sense: the way in which living things change and develop over millions of years
senses.dict_examp: Darwin's theory of evolution
senses.lear_examp: I think it is good to have zoos, but we shouldn't try to control natural evolution as we have done until now.

senses.sense: a gradual process of change and development
senses.dict_examp: the evolution of language
senses.lear_examp: Leonardo's studies and projects on mechanics puzzle us and foresee the future evolution of science and technology.

senses.sense: used to emphasize something that is surprising
senses.dict_examp: Everyone danced - even Mick.
senses.lear_examp: You were the only one who wasn't there, even Marcelo was there!

senses.sense: used to emphasize a comparison
senses.dict_examp: Her last film was even better.
senses.lear_examp: When I saw her getting off the train I really was close to breaking down because she looked even more beautiful.

senses.sense: used to emphasize the fact that something does not happen or is not true
senses.dict_examp: "I never cry." "Not even when you hurt yourself really badly?"
senses.lear_examp: We tried to fish, but didn't catch a thing, not even a shoe!

senses.sense: whether or not
senses.dict_examp: Even if you take a taxi, you'll still miss your train.
senses.lear_examp: I often go to parks, with or without the children, even if the weather is not good.

senses.sense: although
senses.dict_examp: Even though he left school at 16, he still managed to become a millionaire.
senses.lear_examp: They didn't give up hope even though they were tired and wet to the bone.

senses.sense: used to emphasize that something surprising is true despite what you have just said
senses.dict_examp: Car prices have gone down a lot, but even so, we couldn't afford to buy one.
senses.lear_examp: I'm sure many of these things happened due to bad luck, but even so, there are some arrangements that, I believe, can easily be improved.

senses.sense: to make as much money as you spent, but no more
senses.dict_examp: The company only managed to break even this year.
senses.lear_examp: Company C does not seem to be doing well. In the year 2000, it just seems to be breaking even.

senses.sense: full of interesting or important events
senses.dict_examp: a very eventful day/journey
senses.lear_examp: Well do I remember a present I was given on one of my most memorable and eventful birthdays.

senses.sense: to develop or make something develop, usually gradually
senses.dict_examp: rapidly evolving technology
senses.lear_examp: This device has evolved from being a large machine into the size of a notebook.

senses.sense: to make something seem larger, better, worse, etc. than it really is

senses.sense: in a way that is easy to see
senses.dict_examp: He evidently likes her.

senses.sense: the part of the day between the afternoon and the night
senses.dict_examp: I'm working late this evening.
senses.lear_examp: She watches TV every evening.

senses.sense: happening or existing at the end of a process or period of time
senses.dict_examp: the eventual winner of the competition
senses.lear_examp: Finally, the most important consequence - and in some way quite a perverse one - is that setting the island on fire leads to the boys' eventual rescue; so, pure destruction here means catharsis (speaking in terms of drama).

senses.sense: very cruel, bad or harmful
senses.dict_examp: an evil monster
senses.lear_examp: She is a very dark and evil person who can't forget the first Mrs. de Winter.

senses.sense: something that is very bad and harmful
senses.dict_examp: Drug-addiction is one of today's great social evils.
senses.lear_examp: It is not simply the confronting of good and evil.

senses.sense: an official test of how much you know about something, or how well you can do something

senses.lear_examp: I will take my exam on December 8.

senses.sense: when you describe something as larger, better, worse, etc. than it really is
senses.dict_examp: a slight/gross exaggeration of the facts
senses.lear_examp: You wrote about "a sudden downpour of rain" which was a huge exaggeration.

senses.sense: in the end, especially after a long time

senses.lear_examp: Anyway Pat eventually apologized to me.

senses.sense: completely correct in every detail

senses.lear_examp: I am looking forward to your next letter to know the exact time of your arrival.

senses.sense: in or to every place

senses.lear_examp: I love the teddy bear because it's soft and I can take it with me everywhere.

senses.sense: an exam
senses.dict_examp: a written examination
senses.lear_examp: We try to improve our English, because we must pass the P.E.T. examination to complete our studies.

senses.sense: when someone looks at or considers something carefully in order to discover something

senses.sense: to be or give a typical example of something

senses.lear_examp: Okonkwo serves to exemplify to the reader the consequences that the Igbo people were suffering.

senses.sense: the rate at which the money of one country can be changed for the money of another country
senses.dict_examp: The Money Ready Reckoner gives the exchange rate for any country you plan to visit and shows how much currency you will get.
senses.lear_examp: I looked around and saw a shop with the notice "Currency exchange". I decided to go in to find out the exchange rate.

senses.sense: extremely good
senses.dict_examp: The food was excellent.
senses.lear_examp: I had an excellent supper and danced with Nat.

senses.sense: when people feel very happy and enthusiastic
senses.dict_examp: The competition is causing a lot of excitement.
senses.lear_examp: However, if you are looking for fun and excitement, I would go for the city.

senses.sense: used to politely get someone's attention
senses.dict_examp: Excuse me, does this bus go to Oxford Street?
senses.lear_examp: While I was waiting for my fast food, someone knocked my shoulder. I turned and saw a girl about my age. I asked: - Excuse me, did you call me?

senses.sense: used to say you are sorry for something that you do without intending to
senses.dict_examp: Oh, excuse me, did I take your seat?
senses.lear_examp: Excuse me, I'm going to miss the English class tomorrow.

senses.sense: used to politely ask someone to repeat something they said because you have not heard it
senses.dict_examp: "Did you see the movie?" "Excuse me? What was that?" "I asked if you saw the movie."
senses.lear_examp: I asked: Excuse me, did you call me?

senses.sense: to forgive someone
senses.dict_examp: Please excuse me for arriving late - my flight was delayed.
senses.lear_examp: I hope you'll excuse me now, I have to do my homework.

senses.sense: to be given as a reason for someone's bad behavior, so that it does not seem so bad
senses.dict_examp: Nothing can excuse that sort of behavior.
senses.lear_examp: Their main goals are to save the animals and/or to show the animals to the public in order to make us take an interest in the animals and in ecology. I think that these purposes can excuse the fact that the animals are locked up, if they have enough space and are treated very well.

senses.sense: a reason that you give to explain why you did something wrong
senses.dict_examp: What was his excuse for being late?
senses.lear_examp: I had no excuse to give for being late with this report.

senses.sense: a false reason that you give to explain why you do something
senses.dict_examp: Nick was just looking for an excuse to call her.
senses.lear_examp: Also shopping for clothes is an excuse to go out with girls!!

senses.sense: to not allow someone or something to take part in an activity or to enter a place
senses.dict_examp: Two students were excluded from the class because they registered late and it was already full.
senses.lear_examp: Lots of students made a different decision and participated in the swimming gala, where nobody was excluded, because there were races for all abilities.

senses.sense: to intentionally not include something
senses.dict_examp: The advertised price excludes the sales tax.
senses.lear_examp: Hungary was excluded from the Formula 1 Calendar and as a result a new country is to be chosen to replace the missing event.

senses.sense: a punctuation mark (!) used at the end of a sentence that expresses surprise, excitement or shock
senses.dict_examp: Her e-mail is full of exclamation points.

senses.sense: physical activity that you do to make your body strong and healthy
senses.dict_examp: You really should get more exercise.
senses.lear_examp: I can also get some exercise with the bicycle.

senses.sense: a short piece of written work which you do to practice something you are learning
senses.dict_examp: The book has exercises at the end of every chapter.
senses.lear_examp: It's a new book and it has all the necessary exercises for secondary school.

senses.sense: a set of actions that a group of soldiers do to practice their skills
senses.dict_examp: The cadets are out on military exercises.
senses.lear_examp: I am not opposed to military exercises, but such a noisy activity cannot be tolerated in a world in which environmental protection should be promoted by everybody, including the army.

senses.sense: to do physical activities to make your body strong and healthy
senses.dict_examp: She exercises most evenings, usually by running.
senses.lear_examp: It's funny how I heard about that; I was at the gym with Sarah, we were exercising when we heard Tom talking about it with John.

senses.sense: to use a power, right, or ability
senses.dict_examp: You should always exercise your right to vote.
senses.lear_examp: However, if you believe that nothing can be done, I have to inform you that we will exercise our legal rights and take action against you.

senses.sense: extremely
senses.dict_examp: an exceptionally gifted student
senses.lear_examp: The tourism section, which interested me the most, was outstanding, exceptionally well-prepared presentations!

senses.sense: more than is necessary or wanted
senses.dict_examp: They accused the police of using excessive force.
senses.lear_examp: However, having 2 indoor courts seems a bit excessive since the problem with the court is the schedule, not the space.

senses.sense: extremely good
senses.dict_examp: He really is an exceptional student.
senses.lear_examp: This trip constitutes an exceptional challenge for me.

senses.sense: very unusual and not likely to happen very often
senses.dict_examp: Visitors are only allowed in exceptional circumstances.
senses.lear_examp: However, there are always some exceptional circumstances in which they fail to understand what is appropriate for them.

senses.sense: to say something suddenly and loudly because you are surprised, annoyed, excited, etc.
senses.dict_examp: "How terrible!" she exclaimed.
senses.lear_examp: Then he would exclaim, "What a wonderful selection," with a robust laugh.

senses.sense: only
senses.dict_examp: an exclusively female audience
senses.lear_examp: In addition, the reduced price mentioned refers exclusively to UK students, which caused significant problems.

senses.sense: in an excited way
senses.dict_examp: She ran excitedly down the hall to greet her cousins.
senses.lear_examp: We talked excitedly about it all the way home.

senses.sense: to look at or consider a person or thing carefully and in detail in order to discover something about them
senses.dict_examp: She picked up the knife and examined it closely.
senses.lear_examp: I examined both of them and finally I discovered that it was a virus changed genetically in order to kill people.

senses.sense: to test someone to see how much they know or how well they can do something
senses.dict_examp: You'll be examined in three main areas: speaking, listening, and reading comprehension.
senses.lear_examp: Be prepared, not only in the areas you will be examined in.

senses.sense: relating to making decisions and managing businesses
senses.dict_examp: an executive director
senses.lear_examp: So I am now an executive director, I have a job and I know very important people in the Romanian Government.

senses.sense: someone who has an important job in a business
senses.dict_examp: a company executive
senses.lear_examp: The main reason why I attended this conference was to learn how international companies select their employees and how I could improve my qualifications as a finance executive.

senses.sense: not including a particular fact, thing or person
senses.dict_examp: The museum is open daily except Mondays.
senses.lear_examp: All of my friends came except you.

senses.sense: used to give a reason why something is not possible or true
senses.dict_examp: I want to go, except that I'm tired.

senses.sense: someone or something that is not included in a rule, group or list or that does not behave in the expected way
senses.dict_examp: There are exceptions to every rule.
senses.lear_examp: The animals looked so sad to me. So I decided to set them free, all of them, without exception.

senses.sense: to be more than a particular number or amount
senses.dict_examp: Sales have exceeded $1 million so far this year.
senses.lear_examp: Our administration costs didn't exceed 5%, the other 10% were the pure costs of the entertainment.

senses.sense: to be much bigger or better than expected
senses.dict_examp: The location of the apartment exceeded our expectations.
senses.lear_examp: The presentation on tourism was brilliant, exceeding my expectations.

senses.sense: to drive faster than you are allowed to according to the law
senses.dict_examp: She was caught exceeding the speed limit.
senses.lear_examp: There are three ground rules you have to follow: stop at stop-signs, don't exceed the speed limit and don't be in the way of other cars.

senses.sense: making you feel very happy and enthusiastic
senses.dict_examp: an exciting movie/game
senses.lear_examp: I enjoyed the game very much, because it was very exciting.

senses.sense: feeling very happy and enthusiastic
senses.dict_examp: Are you getting excited about your vacation?
senses.lear_examp: I am very excited!

senses.sense: when you give something to someone and they give you something else
senses.dict_examp: an exchange  of ideas/information
senses.lear_examp: So, it was a very interesting exchange of ideas.

senses.sense: an arrangement by which students and teachers from one country go to stay with students and teachers in another country

senses.lear_examp: His name is Rob and, like me, he applied to the student exchange program.

senses.sense: to give something to someone and receive something similar from them

senses.lear_examp: She moved to another part of town and we forgot to exchange our addresses.

senses.sense: to take something back to the shop where you bought it and change it for something else

senses.sense: If two people exchange looks, opinions, views, etc., they look at each other, talk to each other, etc.
senses.dict_examp: The group meets every month to exchange their views on a book they have all read.
senses.lear_examp: You can exchange opinions with them as to the way of life in Japan and your country.

senses.sense: expensive and only for people who are rich or of a high social class
senses.dict_examp: an exclusive club/hotel/shop

senses.sense: to be unable to stop looking at someone or something because they are so attractive or interesting
senses.dict_examp: He couldn't take his eyes off the wrapped gifts on the table.
senses.lear_examp: Her daughter, Lourdes Maria, is such a pretty little girl that I couldn't take my eyes off her.

senses.sense: to be good at noticing a particular type of thing
senses.dict_examp: Your son has a very good eye for detail.
senses.lear_examp: She's got an eye for details but a mind like anybody else's.

senses.sense: to look at someone in a direct way, without showing fear or shame
senses.dict_examp: I wanted to look him in the eye and tell him I made a mistake.
senses.lear_examp: One day she looked me in the eyes with a sharp deep look - never have I seen such a deep look - and asked me what was happening and I told her.

senses.sense: to watch carefully for someone or something to appear
senses.dict_examp: Keep an eye out for the delivery truck.
senses.lear_examp: Although individually we try to deliver the best care possible for our individual patients, we do keep an ear or an eye out for the other members of the team that day.

senses.sense: to choose to ignore something that you know is wrong
senses.dict_examp: The restaurant staff often took food home, and their boss turned a blind eye.
senses.lear_examp: Nevertheless, we can't turn a blind eye to this reality.

senses.sense: to be famous and often featured in the media
senses.dict_examp: Her new role means that she will be in the public eye.
senses.lear_examp: But being famous also means that you are always in the public eye, which is a major drawback.

senses.sense: to get someone's attention by looking at them
senses.dict_examp: I tried to catch her eye, but she had already turned away.
senses.lear_examp: All of a sudden she caught my eye and smiled in a sad way.

senses.sense: to be attractive or different enough to be noticed by people
senses.dict_examp: It was the color of his jacket that caught my eye.
senses.lear_examp: Dear Sir, I am writing regarding your newly published article about nutrition, which immediately caught my eye as I was reading your magazine.

senses.sense: If two people see eye to eye, they agree with each other.
senses.dict_examp: My sister didn’t see eye to eye with me.
senses.lear_examp: Although I agree with some of the statements given by the young people, I do not see eye to eye with all of their viewpoints.

senses.sense: to watch carefully for someone or something
senses.dict_examp: Keep your eyes peeled, he should be here any minute.
senses.lear_examp: Ever since, I try to keep my eyes peeled for anything similar.

senses.sense: to watch carefully for someone or something
senses.dict_examp: Keep your eyes open for anything unusual.
senses.lear_examp: While staying in Turkey, for example, people ought to keep their eyes open. Look into life there.

senses.sense: If someone cries their eyes out, they cry a lot about a problem or situation.
senses.dict_examp: When she heard the fire had destroyed the houses, she cried her eyes out.
senses.lear_examp: She passed away when I was six years old.  I cried my eyes out.

senses.sense: extremely quickly
senses.dict_examp: In the blink of an eye, he was gone.
senses.lear_examp: I got dressed in the blink of an eye and I got down to the kitchen almost rolling down the stairs.

senses.sense: in your imagination or memory
senses.dict_examp: In my mind's eye, I imagined the building painted white, with a beautiful garden around it.
senses.lear_examp: He sees her in his mind's eye, running around barefoot, laughing and squealing, wading in the water and running back out, screaming, trying to get away from the breaking waves.

senses.sense: If something can be seen by the naked eye, it is big enough to be seen without special equipment.
senses.dict_examp: These bugs are so tiny you cannot see them with the naked eye.

senses.sense: to move your eyes in a circle to show surprise or disapproval
senses.dict_examp: When I asked her when she thought the building work would be finished, she just rolled her eyes.
senses.lear_examp: This attitude is obvious when, for instance, sales assistants show no patience for the slower reaction of elderly people; when nobody offers a seat to an older person in an overcrowded train; when we roll our eyes about older people's desire for quiet, etc.

senses.sense: when people look directly at each other, for instance when they are talking to each other
senses.dict_examp: There was very little eye contact between them.
senses.lear_examp: I tried to avoid having eye contact with people just because of this humility.

senses.sense: the piece of skin that covers your eyes when you close them
senses.dict_examp: His eyelids drooped with tiredness.

senses.sense: very, or much more than usual
senses.dict_examp: They played extremely well.
senses.lear_examp: The film was extremely funny.

senses.sense: one of the short hairs which grow from the edge of your eyelids
senses.dict_examp: false/long eyelashes

senses.sense: a sport or activity that is exciting and dangerous
senses.dict_examp: I love most extreme sports, such as bungee jumping and white-water rafting.
senses.lear_examp: You can go camping, climb mountains or learn a lot of extreme sports.

senses.sense: someone who is very confident and likes being with other people
senses.dict_examp: She is an extrovert.
senses.lear_examp: She is an extrovert, a sociable person, who loves talking to people and is always ready to sacrifice her free time to make them happy.

senses.sense: very large in amount or degree
senses.dict_examp: extreme pain/danger/wealth
senses.lear_examp: This time I promise that I will take extreme caution with your things.

senses.sense: the most unusual or the most serious possible
senses.dict_examp: extreme weather conditions
senses.lear_examp: It seems to be an extreme case but it is a fact that modern children have no more contact with animal life.

senses.sense: having such strong opinions or beliefs that most people cannot agree with you
senses.dict_examp: extreme views
senses.lear_examp: Consequently, I can now express my disagreement with both articles, mostly because of the extreme opinions they contain.
